<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 276, 178, 292]]<|/det|>
## PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[832, 276, 905, 292]]<|/det|>
0625/62  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 300, 326, 316]]<|/det|>
Paper 6 Alternative to Practical  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[782, 301, 905, 316]]<|/det|>
May/June 2022  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[855, 325, 905, 340]]<|/det|>
1 hour  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 355, 393, 371]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the question paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 384, 359, 400]]<|/det|>
No additional materials are needed.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 230, 434]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 808, 560]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You may use a calculator.- You should show all your working and use appropriate units.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 588, 220, 603]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 604, 728, 636]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 40.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 146, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 920, 104]]<|/det|>
The student places object Q on the metre rule and adjusts its position until the metre rule is as close to balancing as possible.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 117, 836, 134]]<|/det|>
She records the distance \(a = 40.0 \text{cm}\) between the centre of object P and the pivot.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 149, 532, 166]]<|/det|>
The centre of object Q is at the \(71.2 \text{cm}\) mark.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 180, 920, 212]]<|/det|>
Determine, and record in Table 1.1, the distance \(b\) between the centre of object Q and the pivot. Show your working.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 272, 920, 291]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 144, 89]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 918, 103]]<|/det|> She repeats the procedure with object P placed at the \(15.0 \text{cm}\) mark, \(20.0 \text{cm}\) mark, \(25.0 \text{cm}\) mark and \(30.0 \text{cm}\) mark. All the values of \(a\) and \(b\) are shown in Table 1.1. <|ref|>table_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[457, 114, 541, 131]]<|/det|> Table 1.1 <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[361, 144, 636, 257]]<|/det|>

<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 667, 91]]<|/det|>
A student investigates the resistances of combinations of resistors.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 102, 520, 121]]<|/det|>
The first circuit arrangement is shown in Fig. 2.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[242, 131, 737, 327]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 348, 532, 367]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 2.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 380, 144, 399]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 380, 920, 414]]<|/det|>
The student measures the current and decides to use a lower current. He adds a variable resistor to the circuit to reduce the current.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 426, 841, 445]]<|/det|>
On Fig. 2.1, mark with an \(\mathbf{X}\) a suitable position in the circuit for the variable resistor.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 426, 920, 445]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[129, 457, 865, 628]]<|/det|>

<label>Fig. 2.2</label>

<label>Fig. 2.3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 676, 146, 694]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 676, 180, 694]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 676, 917, 695]]<|/det|>
The student measures the current \(I_{1}\) in the circuit. Record the current shown in Fig. 2.2.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[547, 706, 920, 725]]<|/det|>
<form>\(I_{1} =\) ....................................................A [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 737, 181, 756]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 737, 880, 756]]<|/det|>
He measures the potential difference (p.d.) \(V_{1}\) across resistors \(\mathsf{R}_{\mathsf{A}}\) and \(\mathsf{R}_{\mathsf{B}}\) in series.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 768, 625, 787]]<|/det|>
Record the potential difference \(V_{1}\) shown in Fig. 2.3.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[544, 798, 920, 817]]<|/det|>
<form>\(V_{1} =\) ....................................................V [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 144, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 71, 861, 91]]<|/det|>
Calculate the resistance \(R_{1}\) of the combination of resistors in series. Use the equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[460, 91, 537, 123]]<|/det|>
\[R_{1} = \frac{V_{1}}{I_{1}}.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 133, 291, 152]]<|/det|>
Include the unit.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[541, 193, 920, 213]]<|/det|>
<form>R_1 = .................................................... [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 225, 146, 244]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 225, 740, 245]]<|/det|>
The student connects a resistor \(\mathsf{R}_{\mathsf{C}}\) in parallel with resistors \(\mathsf{R}_{\mathsf{A}}\) and \(\mathsf{R}_{\mathsf{B}}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 255, 710, 275]]<|/det|>
He does **not** change the series combination of resistors \(\mathsf{R}_{\mathsf{A}}\) and \(\mathsf{R}_{\mathsf{B}}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 286, 742, 306]]<|/det|>
He connects the voltmeter across the combination of all three resistors.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 319, 183, 338]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 319, 678, 338]]<|/det|>
Draw a circuit diagram showing the circuit described in (d).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 613, 920, 631]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 644, 181, 663]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 644, 604, 663]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[546, 686, 920, 710]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 720, 900, 740]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[546, 763, 920, 785]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 798, 824, 817]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 617, 920, 650]]<|/det|>
A student thinks the three resistors \(\mathsf{R}_{\mathsf{A}}, \mathsf{R}_{\mathsf{B}}\) and \(\mathsf{R}_{\mathsf{C}}\) have the same resistance within the limits of experimental accuracy.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 660, 180, 678]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 660, 811, 678]]<|/det|>
Suggest how the student could use the apparatus provided to test his idea.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 802, 180, 821]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 802, 920, 835]]<|/det|>
Explain how the student can decide whether the values of resistance are the same within the limits of experimental accuracy.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[850, 904, 920, 922]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 96, 89]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 517, 89]]<|/det|> A student determines the focal length \(f\) of a lens. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 102, 336, 120]]<|/det|> Fig. 3.1 shows the set-up. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[198, 133, 779, 319]]<|/det|> <|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 339, 534, 357]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 370, 144, 389]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 370, 180, 389]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 370, 831, 389]]<|/det|> On Fig. 3.1, measure the distance \(x\) from the screen to the illuminated object. <|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[554, 401, 917, 420]]<|/det|> \[x = ....................................................\] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 432, 920, 466]]<|/det|> Fig. 3.1 is drawn to scale. The actual distance \(D\) between the illuminated object and the screen is \(75.0 \text{cm}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 478, 920, 512]]<|/det|> She places the lens between the object and the screen so that the lens is close to the illuminated object. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 524, 920, 559]]<|/det|> She moves the lens away from the object until a clearly focused image is formed on the screen. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 572, 920, 605]]<|/det|> On Fig. 3.1, measure the distance \(y\) between the centre of the lens and the illuminated object. <|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[554, 618, 917, 636]]<|/det|> \[y = ............................................................\] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 648, 878, 667]]<|/det|> On Fig. 3.1, measure the distance z between the centre of the lens and the screen. <|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[554, 680, 920, 698]]<|/det|> \[z = ............................................................\] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 696, 920, 714]]<|/det|> [2] <|ref|>table_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[457, 726, 541, 744]]<|/det|> Table 3.1 <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[280, 758, 717, 841]]<|/det|>
\(D/ \text{cm}\)\(u/ \text{cm}\)\(v/ \text{cm}\)\(f/ \text{cm}\)
75.0
85.019.164.114.4

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 72, 181, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
Calculate, and record in Table 3.1, the actual distance \(u\) between the centre of the lens and the illuminated object.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 117, 920, 152]]<|/det|>
Calculate, and record in Table 3.1, the actual distance \(v\) between the centre of the lens and the screen.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 149, 920, 166]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 180, 180, 198]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 180, 868, 198]]<|/det|>
Calculate, and record in Table 3.1, the focal length \(f\) of the lens using the equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[468, 201, 529, 230]]<|/det|>
\[f = \frac{uv}{D}.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 227, 920, 245]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 256, 146, 275]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 256, 848, 275]]<|/det|>
The student places the screen at a distance \(D = 85.0 \text{cm}\) from the illuminated object.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 287, 809, 306]]<|/det|>
She repeats the procedure described in (a). The results are shown in Table 3.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 319, 821, 338]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[549, 380, 920, 400]]<|/det|>

State two precautions that you would take to obtain accurate readings in this experiment.

1. ................................................................

................................................................

<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 581, 920, 631]]<|/det|>
A student states that a more accurate value for the focal length \(f\) of the lens can be determined by plotting a graph of \(uv\) against \(D\). The gradient of the graph is numerically equal to the focal length.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 644, 181, 662]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 644, 813, 662]]<|/det|>

<mark>[1]

<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 705, 920, 739]]<|/det|>

<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[833, 860, 920, 878]]<|/det|>

<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 390, 88]]<|/det|>
A student investigates insulators.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 102, 834, 120]]<|/det|>
Plan an experiment to list insulating discs in order from best insulator to worst insulator.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 134, 420, 151]]<|/det|>
The following apparatus is available:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 165, 181, 181]]<|/det|>
<label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 164, 603, 181]]<|/det|>
five discs made from different insulating materials

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 183, 316, 198]]<|/det|>
a thermometer

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 198, 304, 214]]<|/det|>
a stop-watch

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 214, 504, 230]]<|/det|>
a heated metal cylinder (see Fig. 4.1)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 228, 772, 245]]<|/det|>
a second metal cylinder with a hole for the thermometer (see Fig. 4.1).

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 256, 766, 389]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 408, 532, 426]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 4.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 440, 908, 457]]<|/det|>
You can also use other apparatus and materials that are usually available in a school laboratory.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 472, 324, 489]]<|/det|>
In your plan, you should:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 503, 655, 520]]<|/det|>
explain briefly how you would carry out the investigation

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 534, 569, 551]]<|/det|>
state the key variables that you would control

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 565, 918, 597]]<|/det|>
draw a table, or tables, with column headings, to show how you would display your readings (you are **not** required to enter any readings in the table)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 611, 720, 628]]<|/det|>
explain how you would use your readings to reach a conclusion.
